text:
Amazon EMR Serverless makes it easy for data 
analysts and engineers to run open-source big

data analytics frameworks without configuring, 
managing, and scaling clusters or servers. Let’s

head over to the Amazon EMR console and try it 
for ourselves. First, we need to select an EMR

Studio. I’ve already created this "Demo" EMR 
Studio ahead of time, but you can create your own

if necessary using the "Studios" link. Next, we’ll 
click "Manage Applications" to be signed in to

EMR Studio. Let’s create an application to use for 
running our jobs. We’ll call it

"my-emr-serverless-demo-application", choose 
"Spark" for the application type, and leave the

pre-selected release version alone. We’re going to 
use the default application setup options for this

demo, but let’s take a moment to see what 
customizations are available.

Spark applications have a pre-initialized pool of Spark 
workers available to respond in seconds so that our jobs

can begin immediately. Here, we can configure 
their vCPUs, memory, and storage capacity

according to our application’s needs, or disable 
pre-initialization entirely. Next, we can set overall

limits to the aggregate CPU, memory, and disk 
that all running jobs are allowed to consume at a

given moment, or disable those limitations if we 
wish. We can also disable the Auto Start on job

submission and Auto Stop when idle settings, or 
change the maximum idle time. Finally, we can

grant our application additional network access to 
resources within our VPC, and of course, apply

additional tagging. Let’s go ahead and create our 
application using the default settings.

Now that our application has been created, let’s open it 
up and submit a job. We’ll call it "my-demo-spark-job"

and select an IAM role for the job to assume, 
which will grant it access to Amazon EMR,

Amazon S3, and AWS Glue. For this job, we’ll use 
a script that processes several hundred

megabytes of historical New York City taxi data, 
converts it to Apache Parquet format, and creates

a table for it in an AWS Glue data catalog. After 
providing the S3 input and output locations for the

data, we’ll leave the remaining job settings at their 
defaults and click "Submit Job".

Since our application is already started, the job begins 
running immediately. From here, we can open the

Spark UI and monitor the progress of our job or 
delve into further details. If we return to EMR

Studio, we see that the job completed successfully 
in just a few minutes, and we can click on the Job

ID for additional information, such as the total 
resource utilization. Finally, if we head over to the

AWS Glue console, we can see that our script 
created the "nytaxidb" database and a

"yellowtaxiparquet" table with a schema 
corresponding to the input data.

To learn more about how you can get all the features 
and benefits of Amazon EMR without the need for

experts to plan and manage clusters, visit 
aws.amazon.com/emr/serverless and get started today!
